intro: Grevillea amplexans subsp. amplexans, commonly known as the coastal grevillea, is a shrub native to the coastal regions of southern Australia. It is characterized by its striking, bright red flowers that appear in clusters, typically from late winter to spring. The plant has narrow, linear leaves that are often arranged in a spiral pattern along the stems. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it well-suited for coastal and sandy environments. The subspecies is noted for its resilience to salt spray and strong winds, contributing to its ecological significance in coastal ecosystems.
